clinical_study.brief_title: COMMENCE Pulmonary: Clinical Evaluation of Edwards Pericardial Aortic Bioprosthesis (Model 11000A) for Pulmonary Valve Replacement
clinical_study.official_title: Prospective, Non‐Randomized, Single Arm, Multicenter Clinical Evaluation of the Edwards Pericardial Aortic Bioprosthesis (Model 11000A) for Pulmonary Valve Replacement

brief_summary.textblock: The objective of this trial is to assess the safety and effectiveness of the Edwards Pericardial Aortic Bioprosthesis Model 11000A, in the pulmonary position in pediatric and adult subjects five years or older requiring replacement of their native or prosthetic pulmonary valve.

detailed_description.textblock: This is a prospective, Non-Randomized, Single Arm, Multicenter study. Up to one hundred (100) pulmonary valve replacement (PVR) subjects at up to ten (10) clinical sites will be enrolled. Clinical data will be collected from at least 3 centers with data available on patients who have completed the 1 year follow-up visit. Subjects will be followed for and assessed after implant for up to 5 years.

primary_outcome.measure: Percent of Subject's With Freedom From Device or Procedure Related Death and/or Reoperation at 1 Year Post-implant.
primary_outcome.description: Subject's freedom from device or procedure related death and/or reoperation at 1 year post-implant. Time to events were estimated by Kaplan-Meier method.

secondary_outcome.description: 1) All cause mortality, 2) All/Major paravalvular leak, 3) All/Major transvalvular leak, 4) Endocarditis, 5) Explant, 6) Thromboembolism, 7) Valve-related reoperation, 8) Structural valve deterioration, 9) Non-structural valve deterioration, 10) Trial valve-related mortality, 11) Valve thrombosis, 12) All/Major valve-related bleeding, 13) Hemolysis

secondary_outcome.time_frame: 6 months, and annually for up to 5 years
secondary_outcome.description: 1) All cause mortality, 2) All/Major paravalvular leak, 3) All/Major transvalvular leak, 4) Endocarditis, 5) Explant, 6) Thromboembolism, 7) Valve-related reoperation, 8) Structural valve deterioration, 9) Non-structural valve deterioration, 10) Trial valve-related mortality, 11) Valve thrombosis, 12) All/Major valve-related bleeding, 13) Hemolysis

secondary_outcome.time_frame: Baseline, 6 months, and annually thereafter for up to 5 years
secondary_outcome.description: Mean gradient is the average flow of blood through the aortic valve measured in millimeters of mercury. Gradients are evaluated by echocardiography over time. Mean gradient values depend on the size and type of valve.

secondary_outcome.time_frame: Baseline, 6 months, and annually thereafter for up to 5 years
secondary_outcome.description: Peak gradient is the maximum value measured of flow of blood through the aortic valve as measured in millimeters of mercury. Gradients are evaluated by echocardiography over time.

secondary_outcome.time_frame: Baseline, 6 months, and annually thereafter for up to 5 years
secondary_outcome.description: Valvular regurgitation occurs when the valve in the heart does not close tightly allowing some of the blood that was pumped out of the heart to leak back into it. Valvular regurgitation is evaluated by echocardiography over time. It is assessed on a scale from 0 to 4, where 0 represents no regurgitation and 4 represents severe regurgitation.

secondary_outcome.time_frame: Baseline, 6 months, and annually thereafter for up to 5 years
secondary_outcome.description: Tricuspid regurgitation (TR) gradient (peak systolic) is defined as the maximum value measured of blood flowing back through the tricuspid valve during systole as measured in millimeters of mercury.

secondary_outcome.time_frame: Baseline, 6 months, and annually thereafter for up to 5 years
secondary_outcome.description: Peak velocity is defined as the maximum speed in meters per second that the blood is flowing through the pulmonic heart valve in a given direction.

secondary_outcome.time_frame: Baseline, 6 months, and annually thereafter for up to 5 years
secondary_outcome.description: The Doppler Velocity Index (DVI) is a calculation of the ratio of the subvalvular velocity obtained by pulse wave Doppler and the maximum velocity obtained by continuous wave Doppler across the prosthetic valve.

secondary_outcome.time_frame: Baseline, 6 months, and annually thereafter for up to 5 years
secondary_outcome.description: Tricuspid valvular regurgitation velocity time interval (VTI) is defined as the measurement in centimeters of the blood flowing backwards through the tricuspid valve, averaged over time.

secondary_outcome.measure: Subject's New York Heart Association (NYHA) Functional Class for Subjects Older Than 12 Years
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Baseline, 30 days, 6 months, and annually thereafter for up to 5 years
secondary_outcome.description: The New York Heart Association (NYHA) functional classification system relates symptoms to everyday activities and the patient's quality of life. Class I. No limitation of physical activity. Ordinary physical activity does not cause undue fatigue, palpitation, dyspnea (shortness of breath). Class II. Slight limitation of physical activity. Comfortable at rest. Ordinary physical activity results in fatigue, palpitation, dyspnea (shortness of breath). Class III. Marked limitation of physical activity. Comfortable at rest. Less than ordinary activity causes fatigue, palpitation, or dyspnea. Class IV. Unable to carry on any physical activity without discomfort. Symptoms of heart failure at rest. If any physical activity is undertaken, discomfort increases.

secondary_outcome.measure: Cross-tabulation of New York Heart Association (NYHA) Functional Class for Subjects Older Than 12 Years
secondary_outcome.description: The New York Heart Association (NYHA) functional classification system relates symptoms to everyday activities and the patient's quality of life. Class I. No limitation of physical activity. Ordinary physical activity does not cause undue fatigue, palpitation, dyspnea (shortness of breath). Class II. Slight limitation of physical activity. Comfortable at rest. Ordinary physical activity results in fatigue, palpitation, dyspnea (shortness of breath). Class III. Marked limitation of physical activity. Comfortable at rest. Less than ordinary activity causes fatigue, palpitation, or dyspnea. Class IV. Unable to carry on any physical activity without discomfort. Symptoms of heart failure at rest. If any physical activity is undertaken, discomfort increases.

secondary_outcome.measure: Modified Ross Heart Failure Classification for Subjects 12 Years and Under
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Baseline, 30 days, 6 months, and annually for up to 5 years
secondary_outcome.description: The Modified Ross Heart Failure classification system relates symptoms to everyday activities and the adolescent patient's quality of life. Class I. No limitations or symptoms Class II. Infants: Mild tachypnea or diaphoresis with feeding Older children: Mild to moderate dyspnea on exertion Class III. Infants: Growth failure and marked tachypnea or diaphoresis with feeding Older children: Marked dyspnea on exertion Class IV. Symptoms at rest such as tachypnea, retractions, grunting, or diaphoresis

secondary_outcome.measure: Cross-tabulation of Modified Ross Heart Failure Classification for Subjects 12 Years and Under
secondary_outcome.description: The Modified Ross Heart Failure classification system relates symptoms to everyday activities and the adolescent patient's quality of life. Class I. No limitations or symptoms Class II. Infants: Mild tachypnea or diaphoresis with feeding Older children: Mild to moderate dyspnea on exertion Class III. Infants: Growth failure and marked tachypnea or diaphoresis with feeding Older children: Marked dyspnea on exertion Class IV. Symptoms at rest such as tachypnea, retractions, grunting, or diaphoresis

other_outcome.measure: Subject's Average White Blood Cell Count
other_outcome.time_frame: Baseline, 6 months, and annually for up to 5 years
other_outcome.description: Laboratory analysis of White Blood Cell Count on blood drawn from subject; WBC fight infection.

other_outcome.measure: Subject's Average Red Blood Cells Count
other_outcome.time_frame: Baseline, 6 months, and annually for up to 5 years
other_outcome.description: Laboratory Analysis of Red Blood Cell Count on blood drawn from subjects; RBC carry oxygen.

other_outcome.time_frame: Baseline, 30 days, 6 months, and annually for up to 5 years
other_outcome.description: Laboratory Analysis of Hemoglobin Count on blood drawn from subjects. Hemoglobin is an oxygen-carrying protein in red blood cells.

other_outcome.time_frame: Baseline, 6 months, and annually for up to 5 years
other_outcome.description: Laboratory Analysis of Hematocrit Percentage on blood drawn from subjects. Hematocrit is the proportion of red blood cells to the fluid component(plasma) in the blood.

other_outcome.time_frame: Baseline, 6 months, and annually for up to 5 years
other_outcome.description: Laboratory Analysis of Platelet Count on blood drawn from subjects; platelets help with blood clotting.

other_outcome.measure: Subject's Average Plasma Free Hemoglobin or Haptoglobin or Serum LDH
other_outcome.time_frame: Baseline, 6 months, and annually for up to 5 years
other_outcome.description: Laboratory Analysis on blood drawn from subjects. Plasma free hemoglobin test measures the level of free hemoglobin in the liquid part of the blood (the serum). Haptoglobin is a protein produced by the liver. The lactate dehydrogenase (LDH) test looks for signs of damage to the body's tissues.

other_outcome.measure: Subject's Average International Normalized Ratio(INR)/Partial Thromboplastin Time(PTT)
other_outcome.time_frame: Baseline, 6 months, and annually for up to 5 years
other_outcome.description: The INR is a calculation based on results of a prothrombin time (PT). The PT is a blood test that measures the time it takes for the liquid portion (plasma) of the blood to clot. PTT is a blood test that looks at how long it takes for the blood to clot.

other_outcome.measure: Urine Urobilinogen (if Necessary for Subjects 12 Years and Under)
other_outcome.time_frame: Baseline, 6 months, and annually for up to 5 years
other_outcome.description: Laboratory Analysis of urobilinogen in urine measures the amount of urobilinogen in a urine sample. Urobilinogen is formed from the reduction of bilirubin. Bilirubin is a yellowish substance found in your liver that helps break down red blood cells.

intervention.description: Edwards Aortic Bioprosthesis Model 11000A in the pulmonary position; a trileaflet bioprosthesis comprised of bovine pericardium

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
1. Has pulmonary valve disease requiring pulmonary valve replacement of their native or prosthetic valve
2. Is greater than or equal to 5 years of age
3. Subject and/or subject's legal representative has provided written informed consent as approved and required by the respective institutional review board and agrees to its provisions. NOTE: Written consent must be obtained prior to any research related test being performed.
Exclusion criteria:
A subject meeting any of the following criteria shall be excluded:
1. Valve-in-conduit procedure
2. Requires emergency surgery
3. Has acute myocardial infarction (MI) within 30 days prior to screening date
4. Has MRI or CT scan confirmed stroke, cerebrovascular accident (CVA) or transient ischemic attack (TIA) within 6 months (180 days) prior to screening date
5. Has hemodynamic or respiratory instability requiring inotropic support, mechanical circulatory support, or mechanical ventilation within 30 days prior to screening date
6. Has active endocarditis/myocarditis or endocarditis/myocarditis within 3 months prior to screening date
7. Has renal insufficiency as determined by creatinine (S-Cr) level ~ 2.5 mg/dL within 60 days prior to screening visit or end-stage renal disease
8. Has documented leukopenia (WBC < 3.5x 103/I-lL), acute anemia (Hgb <10.0 g/dL or 6 mmol/L), or thrombocytopenia (platelet count < 50xl03/I-lL) accompanied by history of bleeding diathesis or coagulopathy within 60 days prior to screening date
9. Diagnosed with abnormal calcium metabolism and/or hyperparathyroidism
10. Echocardiographic evidence of an intra-cardiac mass, thrombus, or vegetation
11. RVOT aneurysm unless treated during pulmonary valve replacement surgery
12. Has prior organ transplant or is currently an organ transplant candidate
13. Was previously implanted with INSPIRIS RESILIA Pulmonary valve
14. Previously implanted with an aortic, mitral, or tricuspid bioprosthetic valve, mechanical valve, or annuloplasty ring
15. Need for concomitant replacement of the aortic, mitral or tricuspid valves
16. Has presence of non-cardiac disease limiting life expectancy to less than 12 months
17. Is Currently or has recently participated (within 6 weeks) in another investigational drug or device trial
18. Positive urine or serum pregnancy test in female subjects of child-bearing potential and/or nursing mothers, or planning to become pregnant within 1 year of study valve implant
19. Has left ventricular ejection fraction ≤20% as validated by diagnostic procedure prior to screening date
20. Currently incarcerated or unable to give voluntary informed consent
21. Documented history of substance (drug or alcohol) abuse within the last 5 years prior to screening date
22. Patients with hypersensitivity to metal alloys that contain cobalt, chromium, nickel, molybdenum, manganese, carbon, beryllium and iron
23. Patients with hypersensitivity to latex
Intra-Op Exclusion Criterion:
24. Significant injury to the heart upon entry defined as emergent cardiopulmonary bypass requiring femoral cannulation

provided_document.document_type: Study Protocol and Statistical Analysis Plan

group.title: Edwards Pericardial Aortic Bioprosthesis Model 11000A
group.description: Edwards Pericardial Aortic Bioprosthesis Model 11000A in the pulmonary position in subjects five years or older requiring replacement of their native or prosthetic pulmonary valve.

participants_list.participants: One subject missed the 1 year follow-up visit.

group.title: Edwards Pericardial Aortic Bioprosthesis Model 11000A
group.description: Edwards Pericardial Aortic Bioprosthesis Model 11000A in the pulmonary position in subjects five years or older requiring replacement of their native or prosthetic pulmonary valve.

measure.title: Race and Ethnicity Not Collected
measure.population: Race and Ethnicity were not collected from any participant.

outcome.title: Percent of Subject's With Freedom From Device or Procedure Related Death and/or Reoperation at 1 Year Post-implant.
outcome.description: Subject's freedom from device or procedure related death and/or reoperation at 1 year post-implant. Time to events were estimated by Kaplan-Meier method.
outcome.time_frame: 1 year post-implant
outcome.population: The outcome is reported for subjects who received the Edwards Pericardial Aortic Bioprosthesis Model 11000A device where data is available.

group.title: Edwards Pericardial Aortic Bioprosthesis Model 11000A
group.description: Edwards Pericardial Aortic Bioprosthesis Model 11000A in the pulmonary position in subjects five years or older requiring replacement of their native or prosthetic pulmonary valve.

measure.title: Percent of Subject's With Freedom From Device or Procedure Related Death and/or Reoperation at 1 Year Post-implant.
measure.description: Subject's freedom from device or procedure related death and/or reoperation at 1 year post-implant. Time to events were estimated by Kaplan-Meier method.
measure.population: The outcome is reported for subjects who received the Edwards Pericardial Aortic Bioprosthesis Model 11000A device where data is available.

outcome.title: Early Adverse Events
outcome.description: 1) All cause mortality, 2) All/Major paravalvular leak, 3) All/Major transvalvular leak, 4) Endocarditis, 5) Explant, 6) Thromboembolism, 7) Valve-related reoperation, 8) Structural valve deterioration, 9) Non-structural valve deterioration, 10) Trial valve-related mortality, 11) Valve thrombosis, 12) All/Major valve-related bleeding, 13) Hemolysis
outcome.time_frame: 30 days

outcome.title: Late Adverse Events
outcome.description: 1) All cause mortality, 2) All/Major paravalvular leak, 3) All/Major transvalvular leak, 4) Endocarditis, 5) Explant, 6) Thromboembolism, 7) Valve-related reoperation, 8) Structural valve deterioration, 9) Non-structural valve deterioration, 10) Trial valve-related mortality, 11) Valve thrombosis, 12) All/Major valve-related bleeding, 13) Hemolysis
outcome.time_frame: 6 months, and annually for up to 5 years

outcome.title: Subject's Average Mean Gradient
outcome.description: Mean gradient is the average flow of blood through the aortic valve measured in millimeters of mercury. Gradients are evaluated by echocardiography over time. Mean gradient values depend on the size and type of valve.
outcome.time_frame: Baseline, 6 months, and annually thereafter for up to 5 years

outcome.title: Subject's Average Peak Gradients
outcome.description: Peak gradient is the maximum value measured of flow of blood through the aortic valve as measured in millimeters of mercury. Gradients are evaluated by echocardiography over time.
outcome.time_frame: Baseline, 6 months, and annually thereafter for up to 5 years

outcome.title: Subject's Amount of Valvular Regurgitation
outcome.description: Valvular regurgitation occurs when the valve in the heart does not close tightly allowing some of the blood that was pumped out of the heart to leak back into it. Valvular regurgitation is evaluated by echocardiography over time. It is assessed on a scale from 0 to 4, where 0 represents no regurgitation and 4 represents severe regurgitation.
outcome.time_frame: Baseline, 6 months, and annually thereafter for up to 5 years

outcome.title: TR Gradient
outcome.description: Tricuspid regurgitation (TR) gradient (peak systolic) is defined as the maximum value measured of blood flowing back through the tricuspid valve during systole as measured in millimeters of mercury.
outcome.time_frame: Baseline, 6 months, and annually thereafter for up to 5 years

outcome.title: Peak Velocity
outcome.description: Peak velocity is defined as the maximum speed in meters per second that the blood is flowing through the pulmonic heart valve in a given direction.
outcome.time_frame: Baseline, 6 months, and annually thereafter for up to 5 years

outcome.title: Doppler Velocity Index (DVI)
outcome.description: The Doppler Velocity Index (DVI) is a calculation of the ratio of the subvalvular velocity obtained by pulse wave Doppler and the maximum velocity obtained by continuous wave Doppler across the prosthetic valve.
outcome.time_frame: Baseline, 6 months, and annually thereafter for up to 5 years

outcome.title: Transvalvular VTI
outcome.description: Tricuspid valvular regurgitation velocity time interval (VTI) is defined as the measurement in centimeters of the blood flowing backwards through the tricuspid valve, averaged over time.
outcome.time_frame: Baseline, 6 months, and annually thereafter for up to 5 years

outcome.title: Subject's New York Heart Association (NYHA) Functional Class for Subjects Older Than 12 Years
outcome.description: The New York Heart Association (NYHA) functional classification system relates symptoms to everyday activities and the patient's quality of life. Class I. No limitation of physical activity. Ordinary physical activity does not cause undue fatigue, palpitation, dyspnea (shortness of breath). Class II. Slight limitation of physical activity. Comfortable at rest. Ordinary physical activity results in fatigue, palpitation, dyspnea (shortness of breath). Class III. Marked limitation of physical activity. Comfortable at rest. Less than ordinary activity causes fatigue, palpitation, or dyspnea. Class IV. Unable to carry on any physical activity without discomfort. Symptoms of heart failure at rest. If any physical activity is undertaken, discomfort increases.
outcome.time_frame: Baseline, 30 days, 6 months, and annually thereafter for up to 5 years

outcome.title: Cross-tabulation of New York Heart Association (NYHA) Functional Class for Subjects Older Than 12 Years
outcome.description: The New York Heart Association (NYHA) functional classification system relates symptoms to everyday activities and the patient's quality of life. Class I. No limitation of physical activity. Ordinary physical activity does not cause undue fatigue, palpitation, dyspnea (shortness of breath). Class II. Slight limitation of physical activity. Comfortable at rest. Ordinary physical activity results in fatigue, palpitation, dyspnea (shortness of breath). Class III. Marked limitation of physical activity. Comfortable at rest. Less than ordinary activity causes fatigue, palpitation, or dyspnea. Class IV. Unable to carry on any physical activity without discomfort. Symptoms of heart failure at rest. If any physical activity is undertaken, discomfort increases.
outcome.time_frame: Baseline and 1 Year

outcome.title: Modified Ross Heart Failure Classification for Subjects 12 Years and Under
outcome.description: The Modified Ross Heart Failure classification system relates symptoms to everyday activities and the adolescent patient's quality of life. Class I. No limitations or symptoms Class II. Infants: Mild tachypnea or diaphoresis with feeding Older children: Mild to moderate dyspnea on exertion Class III. Infants: Growth failure and marked tachypnea or diaphoresis with feeding Older children: Marked dyspnea on exertion Class IV. Symptoms at rest such as tachypnea, retractions, grunting, or diaphoresis
outcome.time_frame: Baseline, 30 days, 6 months, and annually for up to 5 years

outcome.title: Cross-tabulation of Modified Ross Heart Failure Classification for Subjects 12 Years and Under
outcome.description: The Modified Ross Heart Failure classification system relates symptoms to everyday activities and the adolescent patient's quality of life. Class I. No limitations or symptoms Class II. Infants: Mild tachypnea or diaphoresis with feeding Older children: Mild to moderate dyspnea on exertion Class III. Infants: Growth failure and marked tachypnea or diaphoresis with feeding Older children: Marked dyspnea on exertion Class IV. Symptoms at rest such as tachypnea, retractions, grunting, or diaphoresis
outcome.time_frame: Baseline and 1 Year

outcome.title: Subject's Average White Blood Cell Count
outcome.description: Laboratory analysis of White Blood Cell Count on blood drawn from subject; WBC fight infection.
outcome.time_frame: Baseline, 6 months, and annually for up to 5 years

outcome.title: Subject's Average Red Blood Cells Count
outcome.description: Laboratory Analysis of Red Blood Cell Count on blood drawn from subjects; RBC carry oxygen.
outcome.time_frame: Baseline, 6 months, and annually for up to 5 years

outcome.title: Subject's Average Hemoglobin Count
outcome.description: Laboratory Analysis of Hemoglobin Count on blood drawn from subjects. Hemoglobin is an oxygen-carrying protein in red blood cells.
outcome.time_frame: Baseline, 30 days, 6 months, and annually for up to 5 years

outcome.title: Subject's Average Hematocrit Percentage
outcome.description: Laboratory Analysis of Hematocrit Percentage on blood drawn from subjects. Hematocrit is the proportion of red blood cells to the fluid component(plasma) in the blood.
outcome.time_frame: Baseline, 6 months, and annually for up to 5 years

outcome.title: Subject's Average Platelet Count
outcome.description: Laboratory Analysis of Platelet Count on blood drawn from subjects; platelets help with blood clotting.
outcome.time_frame: Baseline, 6 months, and annually for up to 5 years

outcome.title: Subject's Average Plasma Free Hemoglobin or Haptoglobin or Serum LDH
outcome.description: Laboratory Analysis on blood drawn from subjects. Plasma free hemoglobin test measures the level of free hemoglobin in the liquid part of the blood (the serum). Haptoglobin is a protein produced by the liver. The lactate dehydrogenase (LDH) test looks for signs of damage to the body's tissues.
outcome.time_frame: Baseline, 6 months, and annually for up to 5 years

outcome.title: Subject's Average International Normalized Ratio(INR)/Partial Thromboplastin Time(PTT)
outcome.description: The INR is a calculation based on results of a prothrombin time (PT). The PT is a blood test that measures the time it takes for the liquid portion (plasma) of the blood to clot. PTT is a blood test that looks at how long it takes for the blood to clot.
outcome.time_frame: Baseline, 6 months, and annually for up to 5 years

outcome.title: Urine Urobilinogen (if Necessary for Subjects 12 Years and Under)
outcome.description: Laboratory Analysis of urobilinogen in urine measures the amount of urobilinogen in a urine sample. Urobilinogen is formed from the reduction of bilirubin. Bilirubin is a yellowish substance found in your liver that helps break down red blood cells.
outcome.time_frame: Baseline, 6 months, and annually for up to 5 years

reported_events.time_frame: Events occurring from baseline through three years post-implant
reported_events.desc: The outcome is site reported for subjects who received the Edwards Pericardial Aortic Bioprosthesis Model 11000A device where data is available.

group.title: Edwards Pericardial Aortic Bioprosthesis Model 11000A
group.description: Edwards Pericardial Aortic Bioprosthesis Model 11000A in the pulmonary position in subjects five years or older requiring replacement of their native or prosthetic pulmonary valve.

event.sub_title: Bleeding - Peripheral Vascular - Minor (E.G. Nosebleeds; Hematomas)
Nonspecific, Unknown Or Other Body System - Other Complication

certain_agreements.pi_employee: Principal Investigators are NOT employed by the organization sponsoring the study.
certain_agreements.restrictive_agreement: PI can't publish/present on overall study results not yet published but may publish his own data subject to EW review. Manuscripts will be submitted to EW for review 30 days prior to submission of manuscript for publication/presentation. EW may ask for a 60 day delay to protect proprietary information/filing of related patent applications. Site-specific results of devices which haven't been market released shall not include claims of device safety/effectiveness and require EW review/approval.

point_of_contact.name_or_title: Andrey Nersesov, Sr. Director of Clinical Affairs, Surgical Structural Heart
